moves.6. d3: Better than others, blocking the white diagonal in sight of Bc4+. But this allows...
moves.6... Bg4+: ...and whatever white covers with, black takes the N, disrupting white's pawns.
moves.7. Be2 Bxf3 8. gxf3: This can be a disadvantage, in fact: Nf6 seems blocked, Q blocks dsb, and the other N is still unmoved. But white is not much better.
moves.8... c6: Avoiding Nb5 or d5. Maybe not necessary, but Nc6 kept the N jumps "on" for long.
moves.9. Bg5 Nbd7: White wants to castle queenside, so do I.
moves.10. Qd2: Here, black should better go Qb4, preparing lsb's liberation, by threatening b2.
moves.10... O-O-O 11. O-O-O Qe5: ? Well, the idea is to mobilize the queen away from lsb's way.
moves.13. Bg3: Just consolidating. but bad timing for it.
moves.13... Bb4: Threat is set, all of a sudden, it's white's death. There is no defence AFAICS) against Nd5. (* AFAICS: as far as I can see :-).
moves.14. f4: The lsb doesn't come on time for defence.
moves.14... Nd5: Now, let's imagine this position but the WK being in b1, instead: White can go NxN, and if black BxQ, Ne7#! This elegant shocking mate net, with all the pieces around, with just a B and a N, is wonderful. The main reason I saved the game for.
moves.16... Qxa3+ 17. Kb1 Nxc3+: White has to sac the Q to avoid mate.
moves.18. Qxc3 Qxc3 19. Kc1 f5: I hope for resignation, but white seems to want more.
moves.20... Nc5: The last sac. Can you see why white can't take the R?
moves.22. Kb1 Qa1#: A very elegant checkmate, I shall say, with the N "en prise" and just the Q giving check. It is more often seen with a B in c3, instead.
